The Chiefs of Staff reported the principal events of theweek.The operations of Bomber Command had been limited by bad weather. The only major raid had been on Essen, but in three nights 1,100 sea-mines had been laid. 1'During April our home-based bombers had dropped a total of11,180 tons of bombs, of Which 9,600 tons had been dropped on targets in Germany, This represented about 10 per,cent, of thetotal tonnage of bombs dropped on Germany throughout the war.Coastal Command had made 21 attacks on U-boats, several ofwhich had been promising. There were indications that U-boats were beginning to fight back from the surface against air attack;this development was likely to prove expensive for the U-boats.Aircraft operating over France in daylight on Saturday, the1st May, had experienced difficulties through an unexpected changein weather conditions; and a formation of United States Fortresseshad suffered heavy losses over Brest.Enemy losses for the week had been 11 destroyed, 2 probably destroyed and 6 damaged. Our losses had been 37 bombers,10 fighters and 8 Coastal Command aircraft.In the Mediterranean theatre the Allies had flown 10,200sorties, as against an estimated total of 2,200 enemy sorties. our air activity had been concentrated mainly against shipping in theSicilian Channel. Enemy losses were 109 destroyed, 14 probably destroyed and 65 damaged. Our losses had been 75 destroyed and54 damaged. ."Shipping losses by enemy action during the previous week hadbeen 80,000 tons. Of this, 47,000 tons had been lost in April andthe remainder in May.For the month of April the latest estimate of losses by enemy action was 281,000 tons, which might rise to a maximum (includinglosses by marine risk) of 365,000 tons.Seven ships, totalling 38,000 tons, had been sunk in a convoy off Freetown. Owing to heavy commitments in other directions,this convoy had only been lightly protected by naval escorts. Theaircraft which had been accompanying the convoy had been diverted to search for another U-boat" reported in the vicinity, and onreturning had been unable to locate the convoy on account of an exceptionally heavy electric storm.The War Cabinet were informed of the arrangements made for reinforcing the convoy protection, in this area.The Prime Minister asked that a report should be made tohim on the arrangements for providing air protection for thisparticular convoy, and generally for convoys in this area andin thei Mediterranean, where two of our ships had been sunk byan air-attack at dusk.: "..
